title: 107_s2214
content:
The Act may be cited as the "1993 World Trade Center Victims Compensation Act". It includes definitions in Section 101. The Act, known as the "1993 World Trade Center Victims Compensation Act," defines key terms such as claimant, collateral source, and economic loss. Claimant refers to individuals filing for compensation, collateral source includes various sources of compensation related to the 1993 World Trade Center bombing, and economic loss encompasses pecuniary losses resulting from harm. The "1993 World Trade Center Victims Compensation Act" defines terms like eligible individual, noneconomic losses, and Special Master for the September 11th Victim Compensation Fund of 2001. Eligible individuals are those approved for compensation, noneconomic losses cover various nonpecuniary losses, and the Special Master is the appointed official for the fund. The 11th Victim Compensation Fund of 2001 was established under the Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act. The purpose of this title is to compensate individuals affected by the 1993 World Trade Center bombing. The Attorney General will oversee the compensation program and allocate necessary funds for administrative costs. SEC. 104. DETERMINATION OF ELIGIBILITY FOR COMPENSATION. A claimant can file a compensation claim with the Special Master by using a specific form that requests information about physical harm. The form must state the factual basis for eligibility and the amount of compensation sought. The Special Master will ensure the form can be filed electronically if feasible. The claimant must provide information on physical harm, economic and noneconomic losses, and collateral sources of compensation related to the terrorist bombing of the World Trade Center on February 26, 1993. No claim can be filed without this information. The Special Master reviews and determines eligibility, extent of harm, and compensation for claims related to the terrorist bombing of the World Trade Center on February 26, 1993, with a 2-year limitation on filing claims after regulations are promulgated. The Special Master reviews and determines eligibility, extent of harm, and compensation for claims related to the terrorist bombing of the World Trade Center on February 26, 1993. The claimant's individual circumstances are considered, negligence is not a factor, and a final determination is made within 120 days of filing. Claimants have the right to be represented by an attorney and present evidence. The Special Master determines compensation for claims related to the 1993 World Trade Center bombing, including the right to present evidence and no punitive damages. Collateral compensation is deducted from the amount awarded. Eligibility is based on individual circumstances. The Special Master determines compensation for claims related to the 1993 World Trade Center bombing. Eligibility is based on being present at the World Trade Center in New York City during the bombing, suffering physical harm or death as a result, and not being identified by the Attorney. The Special Master determines compensation for claims related to the 1993 World Trade Center bombing. Eligibility is based on being present at the World Trade Center in New York City during the bombing, suffering physical harm or death as a result, and not being identified by the Attorney. Only one claim can be submitted per individual or deceased individual's personal representative. Upon submitting a claim, the claimant waives the right to file a civil action in any Federal or State court. The Special Master determines compensation for claims related to the 1993 World Trade Center bombing. Eligibility is based on being present at the World Trade Center in New York City during the bombing, suffering physical harm or death as a result, and not being identified by the Attorney. Only one claim can be submitted per individual or deceased individual's personal representative. Claimants waive the right to file a civil action in any Federal or State court for damages sustained as a result of the terrorist-related bombing of the World Trade Center on February 26, 1993. Individuals involved in pending civil actions must withdraw from the action within 90 days after regulations are promulgated under section 106 to submit a claim under this title. SEC. 105. PAYMENTS TO ELIGIBLE INDIVIDUALS. The Special Master authorizes payment to claimants within 20 days of determining compensation. This title allows for advance budget authority for compensation payments. The Attorney General can accept contributions for funding under specific conditions. Funds in accounts provided under paragraph (1) must be used before appropriated amounts. SEC. 106. REGULATIONS.

The Attorney General, in consultation with the Special Master, must issue regulations within 90 days of this Act's enactment to implement this title, including forms, information requirements, hearing procedures, filing assistance, and other relevant matters.

SEC. 107. RIGHT OF SUBROGATION.

The United States retains the right of subrogation for any claims paid under this title.

TITLE II--INCOME TAX PROVISIONS

SEC. 201. INCOME TAX RELIEF. SEC. 201. INCOME TAX RELIEF.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include specified terrorist victims from February 26, 1993, to April 19, 1995. The amendment applies to taxable years before, on, or after the enactment date. Allows refunds or credits for overpaid taxes within 1 year of enactment, even if prevented by law.
